metadata.case_name: Appellant (L. Amar Nath Dogra) v. Union of India

facts.text: Public auction on February 25, 1952 at Mandi, Himachal Pradesh for monopoly vend-licence to sell country-liquor for April 1, 1952 to March 31, 1953.
Appellant was highest bidder at Rs. 1,28,600/-, bid accepted.
1/6th of bid (Rs. 21,460/-) deposited within a month.
Appellant started working licence, paid monthly instalments of Rs. 10,714/- for April and May 1952.
Disputes raised by appellant: Excise authorities defaulted in supply of liquor etc.
Appellant stopped sales, served notice u/s 80 CPC on September 2, 1952 claiming damages for breach.
Collector of Excise suspended appellant's licence u/s 36 Punjab Excise Act, 1914; took over vend-shops u/s 39.
Steps taken for recovery of instalments due from June 1952.
Suit No. 345/1952 filed November 26, 1952 for permanent injunction restraining recovery of balance licence fees.
Suit No. 345/1952 withdrawn May 12, 1953 with liberty u/O 23 r.1 CPC to file fresh suit.
Present suit instituted May 5, 1953 in District Judge, Mandi for damages for breach of contract.
District Judge dismissed suit upholding technical objections (s.80 CPC, barred by Punjab Land Revenue Act and Punjab Excise Act) and most merits against appellant.
Appeal to Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh (Regular Civil First Appeal No. 4/1958) dismissed, affirming technical objections and most merits, reversing one item in appellant's favour.
Certificate u/Art. 133(1)(b) rejected; special leave obtained.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit is maintainable for non-compliance with s.80 CPC due to defective notice, variance between notice and plaint, and need for fresh notice after withdrawal.
Whether barred under Punjab Excise Act, 1914 and Punjab Land Revenue Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Substantial compliance with s.80 CPC; notice stated cause of action (breaches) and relief claimed (damages Rs.74,935/8/3); single contract, no need for item-wise details.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.80 CPC; State of Madras v. C.P. Agencies; Dhian Singh Sobha Singh v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Previous notice not exhausted by withdrawn suit; plaint claim limited to notice amount.

respondent_arguments.text: Fresh notice u/s.80 required after withdrawal with liberty; notice defective, not complying with requirements; variance between notice and plaint in cause of action and reliefs.
Suit barred under Punjab Land Revenue Act as applied to Himachal Pradesh and Punjab Excise Act, 1914.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Punjab Excise Act s.36, s.39, s.40; Punjab Land Revenue Act

court_reasoning.text: Compliance with s.80 mandatory; no substantial compliance as notice lacked details of claims under each head, variance between notice (subsisting contract breaches) and plaint (terminated contract, new claims like lost profits post-suspension).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notice must inform nature, basis of claim, reliefs sufficiently for Government to consider and avert suit; here, no identification possible between notice lump sum and plaint items.

court_reasoning.text: No fresh notice needed if prior notice valid, but here invalid; claim for initial deposit barred by s.40 Punjab Excise Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Radical change in cause of action post-notice (licence suspended/cancelled).

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished precedents as those notices had details lacking here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.80 object: enable Government to know claim and decide to accept/resist.

holdings.text: Suit not maintainable due to non-compliance with s.80 CPC; entire claim fails also due to s.40 Punjab Excise Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. C. P. Agencies
precedents_cited.relevance: Object of s.80: inform Government of nature of suit, facts, reliefs to consider claim.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhian Singh Sobha Singh v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: s.80 terms not to be scrutinized pedantically but with commonsense; notice must enable knowing claim.

precedents_cited.case_name: Privy Council case (54 Ind. App. 338, AIR 1927 PC 176)
precedents_cited.relevance: s.80 terms to be strictly complied with.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandatory notice before suit against Government; plaint must state notice delivered; liberty to file fresh suit.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Excise Act, 1914
statutes_cited.relevance: Suspension/cancellation of licence, takeover of shops; no compensation/refund on cancellation under certain clauses.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Land Revenue Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Bar to suit as applied to Himachal Pradesh.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as suit not maintainable for non-compliance with s.80 CPC due to defective notice and variance with plaint; no hearing on merits.

key_quotes.text: No suit shall be instituted against the Government... until the expiration of two months next after notice in writing has been delivered to... stating the cause of action, the name... and the relief which he claims.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.80 CPC, central to holding on mandatory compliance.

key_quotes.text: The object of s.80 is... to give the Government... sufficient notice... so that it... may consider the position and decide... whether the claim... should be accepted or resisted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose of s.80, why notice defective.

key_quotes.text: There is complete variance between the claim made in the notice and the claim in the plaint.
key_quotes.speaker: court
